Towards efficient Pd/Mn3O4 catalyst with enhanced acidic sites and low temperature reducibility for Benzene abatement Tareque Odoom-Wubah a Qun Li b Isroil Adilov b Jiale Huang b ⁎ Qingbiao Li a b a Department of Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China Department of Chemistry College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 PR China Department of Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China b Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 PR China Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The activity of supported Pd catalyst as a result of metal oxide support (zinc, titanium, copper and manganese) is explored in the abatement of C6H6 in the gas-phase. The high-activity and cost-effective catalysts were synthesized utilizing impregnation assisted biosynthesis (IB) method. NH3-TPD, XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, XPS, O2 and Benzene-TPD, SEM and in situ DRIFT were done to probe their physicochemical characteristics and predict the plausible oxidation mechanism. Pd particle size and dispersion, and support active acid sites were the determining factors for activity. These factors markedly affected the catalyst ability to generate surface active O2 species from the metal oxides lattice station and controlled the benzene absorption/desorption rates. The as-synthesized Pd/Mn3O4-O with small crystallite size, good Pd dispersion, improved acid sites, and low activation energy (Ea = 45.3 kJ/mol) showed commendable O2 transportability and activity as low as 140 °C, GHSV of 120,000 mLg−1 h−1. Its T 100 at 240 °C was similar to Pd supported on TiO2 but was 20, 40 and 60 °C better than Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO. In situ DRIFT studies showed that the main intermediate species benzoquinone are oxidized to CO2 and H2O through the alkoxide and acid sites. Moreover, it was stable and highly resistant to H2O vapor. Keywords Acid sites Pd dispersion Mono-dispersed Pd sites Catalytic benzene oxidation Metal oxides Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) both outdoor and indoor are a major atmospheric pollutant worldwide [1,2]. Their effects include reduction in air quality, ozone destruction (HCFC), and irritation to the eyes and skin. Moreover, some are known causes of cancer (benzene, toluene, formaldehyde etc) and their abatement is of paramount importance [3,4]. Direct catalytic abatement of benzene to CO2 and H2O without secondary phase pollutants is relatively cost effective and carried out at much lower temperature and costs. The main drawbacks of this process is reducing the high cost of precious metals, the use of lesser green approaches, and reducing the high temperatures (>300 °C) at which meaningful degradation is achieved. Non-noble metals have been employed but their limitations like moderately high light-off temperatures and structure unsteadiness makes them less desirable compared to nobel metal supported catalyst. However, metal oxides can act as significant supports as they provide enhanced surface areas, improved selectivity, increased thermal suitability and reduce the amount of precious metals needed reducing overall cost of the catalyst [5]. Many catalyst supports are utilized in the VOCs oxidation. Manganese Oxides (MnxOy) base catalysts are one of the most successful catalysts used in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs [6]. Different crystals phases (Mn3O4, Mn2O3, MnO2 and MnO) have all been disclosed because of its abundant oxygen reservoir and efficiency in oxidation/reaction cycles [7,8]. To improve their low temperature oxidation, binary based M-MnxOy (M = Co, Zn, Ce, Al etc) metal oxides were proposed. Wang et.al showed that Ce-Mn oxides with diverse morphologies formed by adding Ce to MnO enhances the low temperature abatement of chlorobenzene and toluene in comparison to single metal oxides [9]. Moreover, Yang et al, showed that Ce2+ modified KL-NY on Mn present an improved performance over mono metal oxides due to improved surface area, reducibility and pore volume [10]. And Deng et.al reported a similar performance for Co-doped Mn-Ce-O solution catalyst in the abatement of benzene [11]. Despite the improvement in low temperature performance they are limited when the tests are conducted at large space time velocities (GHSV > 60,000 g−1 h−1·mL) due to poor O2 transportability and structural instability [10]. Catalyst properties such as acid sites, structure, metal dispersion, composition distribution, and stability are affected by the catalyst preparation conditions [12]. For example treatment of Kaolin with acid or base salts improves its pore structure and specific surface area [13]. In addition, in situ incorporation of CeO2 supported on SiO2 catalysts showed better benzene oxidation activity than those prepared by conventional wet impregnation due to the preparation methods effect on the final catalysts surface area, active oxygen defects and Ce4+/Ce3+ redox properties [14]. The above examples highlight the effect of preparation methods. Recently, producing nanoparticles via biological organisms/its parts both dead/alive is a great alternative over conventional physicochemical methods. Cinnamomum camphora (C. camphora) leaf extract has been employed by our lab to generate mono/alloy supported NPs and metal oxide catalyst for several reactions including hydrogenation [15,16], electro-catalysis [17], and degradation of organic pollutants [18]. In this paper, we synthesized smaller crystallite size Mn3O4-O metal oxides with improved acid sites, specific surface area and structural stability as support by treating Manganese (II) sulfate (MnSO4.H2O) with different base and acid treatments. Then Pd/Mn3O4-O is prepared by combining the advantages of impregnation and bio-reduction. The as-produced catalyst is used in the abatement of benzene at a favorable industrially acceptable GHSV of 120,000 mL· g−1 h−1 and compared to commercial supports (CS) Mn3O4-C, TiO2, ZnO and CuO. Supporting Information is referred to as SI in the manuscript. Experimental section Materials and methods Thoroughly washed and milled C. camphora leaves obtained from Xiamen University campus is sieved with a 50 m sieve mesh and kept for further experiments. Manganese (II) sulfate (MnSO4.H2O), Palladium nitrate Pd (NO3)2, ZnO, CuO, TiO2 and Mn3O4 (referred to as Mn3O4-C) were provided by the reagent company (Sinopharm Chemicals Reagent Co. Ltd). Synthesis of Mn3O4-O Firstly, 1 mL of 0.1 mM (MnSO4.H2O) is put in 40 mL (DI H2O). After 0.1 g of PVP is added and stirred until the PVP totally dissolves. Subsequently, 2.5 mL of (100 mM) C6H8O6 and 200 mM of NaOH are injected dropwise into the mixture using a syringe pump. The additions were programmed such that it was done within 10 min, NaOH first followed by ascorbic acid. Then the mixture is uninterruptedly agitated at room temperature for 5 min, then drop wise addition of 2.5 mL of HNO3 (2 mL in 20 mL H2O) mixture. After, the mixture was centrifuged to obtain the solid which was washed thrice with ethanol. Lastly, the Mn3O4 is kept in the oven for 8 h at 50 °C and then annealed at 500 °C to form Mn3O4-O. Synthesis of the supported Pd catalyst (Pd/SC) Impregnation-bioreduction (IB) procedure was utilized to prepare the various Pd supported catalysts. Typically, 500 mg of the variant supports is first put in measured 0.074 M of Pd (NO3)2 aqueous solutions, and kept on the lab table for 6 h, then freeze-dried at −20 °C for 24 h. C. camphora leaf extract (10 mL of 1 g/L) is introduced into it and the metal solutions undergo in-situ reduction atop the variant supports. And then left at 50 °C for to dry 12 h, thereafter, annealed at desired temperatures. The other Pd supported catalysts were synthesized by replacing Mn3O4-O with the respective supports. Different Pd sizes were synthesized by increasing the leaf extract from 10 to 40 mL. Pd metal loading were controlled between 0.25˜1.5 w% Sample characterizations TEM, EDX an SAED probes were collected on an (Tecnai F30, FEI; Netherlands) electron microscope at a 300 kV accelerating voltage. SEM images were acquired on a (LEO-1530, Germany) electron microscope. Particle sizes estimations of the metal NPs and metal oxides were done using Sigma-Scan PRO 4 software. XRD investigations of the powder catalysts were obtained on (Phillips; Netherlands) X-ray crystallography, possessing an inbuilt Copper Kα (40 kV, 30 mA) radiation. FT-IR assessment was carried out on (a Thermo Nicolet, Nicolet 6700 spectrophotometer; U.S.A). Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) tests were conducted employing the USA (Micromeritics Tristar 3020 system). Metal loading testing via ICP-OES Chemical examination of each catalyst was done to investigate the Pd metal loading. This was carried out via ICP-OES procedure on (VISTA-MPX, Varian; USA). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted on a chemical adsorption analyzer (MFTP-3060, China) by using the H2-Ar (5/95, v/v) mixture as a reducing gas. Prior to the H2-TPR analysis, the samples were pretreated in Ar flow of 50 mL/min at 200 °C for 3 h, and the pretreated samples were heated from RT to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min in the aforementioned reducing gas mixture of 50 mL/min. O2 and Benzene Temperature program desorption (O2 and Benzene-TPD) O2 and Benzene Temperature program desorption (O2 and Benzene-TPD) experiments were conducted on a chemical adsorption analyzer (MFTP-3060, China) by using the O2 (5/95, v/v) or Benzene/ N2 (5/95, v/v). Prior to the O2 and Benzene-TPD analysis, the samples were pretreated in Ar flow of 50 mL/min at 200 °C for 1 h and allowed to cool to RT. And then O2 or Benzene gas was injected into the catalyst chamber at 200 °C for 3 h at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min. Then after cooling to RT, the samples were treated from RT to 900 °C with pure He at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min in the aforementioned gas mixtures of 50 mL/min. NH3-Temperature program desorption (NH3-TPD) NH3-TPD experiments were conducted on a chemical adsorption analyzer (MFTP-3060, China) by using NH3/He (5/95, v/v). Prior to the NH3-TPD analysis, the samples were pretreated in Ar flow of 50 mL/min at 200 °C for 1 h and allowed to cool to RT. And then NH3 gas was injected into the catalyst chamber at 50 °C for 3 h at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min. Then after cooling to RT, the samples were treated from RT to 900 °C with pure He at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min in the aforementioned gas mixtures of 50 mL/min. Pulse CO and H2 chemisorption tests The pulsation chemisorptions both H2 and CO were acquired on ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics) using the static volumetric method [19]. Summarily, (H2 and CO) uptake adsorbate chemisorptions on each sample was done using 0.5 g reduced at 300 °C for 2 h in flowing pure dihydrogen. The chamber is then emptied to ensure total eviction of any chemisorbed groups. The inceptive isotherms are carefully obtained at 35 °C, within (100˜600 Torr) pressure range. Then under similar inceptive conditions a 30 min eviction is done to evacuate any reverse adsorbed adsorbate species on the samples. Subsequently, the repetitive isotherm is acquired. The estimated variation among the inceptive and repetitive isotherms shows the non-reversible chemisorbed adsorbates uptakes of the on each sample. H2-chemisorptions tests were done prior to the CO chemisorptions test. In-situ DRIFTS test DRIFTS testing was carried out on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR within the scale (400 ˜ 3800 cm–1) at a 4 cm–1 test resolution and 32 scans. Prior to testing, N2 gas was allowed into the chamber to pre-treat every sample for 30 min at 250 °C and then left to cool to 40°C. This rids the samples of any adsorbed unwanted species. All the backdrop spectra were conducted in N2 and spontaneously deducted from the tested catalyst spectrum. Then, N2/C6H6 (1000 ppm) is permitted at a 50 mL/min rate of flow into the cell between 40–180 °C and the respective DRIFTS spectrum was acquired. Subsequently, N2 is permitted into the cell to evict any physisorbed C6H6 for 1 h. Finally, the reactions between preadsorbed C6H6 and 20% O2/N2 via the catalyst is done at 40 to 240 °C for diverse time ranges. Catalytic evaluation Procedure The gaseous phase catalytic abatement of C6H6 was carried out under barometric pressure in a 0.01 m size continuous fixed-bed reactor with 50 mg of catalyst. The reactant had 20% of N2/O2 balance in 1000 ppm of C6H6. The hourly estimated space time velocity equaled (GHSV) of 120,000⋅g1 h−1 mL at a 93.5 mL/min rate of flow. The final C6H6 outlet conversion (Bc) was estimated from the corresponding GC peaks consisting of a FID recorder and an Al2O3 column. The formula below was employed to estimate the outlet conversions. (1) B c = C a - C b C b × 100 , Where Ca and Cb are concentrations of input and output benzene Results and discussions XRD, SAED and BET analysis The synthesis pathway of the Pd supported Mn3O4-O catalyst using the impregnation-biosynthesis method is shown in Scheme 1 above. Fig. 1 A presents the XRD patterns of the Mn3O4-O oxide support. It shows low to high angles at 29°, 32.4°, 36.1°, 44.5°, 50.9°, 58.5°, 59.8° and 64.6° corresponding to the (101), (112), (103), (211), (220), (105), (321), (224), and (440) planes respectively of pure Mn3O4 crystalline phase (hausmanite, JCPDS No. 18-0803). This agreed with the SAED analysis, Fig. 1B. A similar pattern was observed for the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst. The XRD pattern of Pd supported on the CS are presented in Fig. S1 page S4, commercial Pd/Mn3O4 (referred to as Pd/Mn3O4-C) matched the crystalline phase of (Mn3O4 hausmanite, JCPDS No. 24-0734) [20]. Pd/TiO2 matched (TiO2, JCPDS No. 65-5714), Pd/ZnO matched card no (ZnO, JCPDS 36–1451) [18] and Pd/CuO matched that of (CuO, JCPDS 45-0937) [21]. No clear peaks for Pd NPs were observed due to their small sizes 1˜ 4 nm and good Pd dispersion [22,23]. The Scherer’s equation below was used to estimate their average crystallite sizes. (2) Cs= Kλ/β cosθ Where β is the Full width at 1 2 maximal intensity (FWHM) in radians, λ = 0.153 = X-ray wavelength, θ = angle of diffraction in degrees, K = 0.89, and Cs = mean crystallite size The crystallite sizes of the various catalysts were 8.1 nm (Pd/Mn3O4-O), 21.8 nm (Pd/Mn3O4-C), 19.5 nm (Pd/TiO2), 25.5 nm (Pd/ZnO) and 33 nm (Pd/CuO) respectively using the diffraction peaks between 30–80 °C. Their BET surface areas were 54.8, 28.6, 50.0, 14.6 and 7.1 m²/g for Pd/Mn3O4-O, Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO respectively. And their BET surface areas without Pd loadings are also presented in Table 1 . TEM, STEM and EDX analysis TEM pictures of the various Pd/SC are reported in Fig. 2 A–E. The mean sizes of Pd NPs annealed at 300 °C on the various supports were <5 nm on all the catalyst. Their particle diameters were 2.6, 2.3, 2.4, 3.6 and 4.3 nm corresponding to Pd/Mn3O4-O, Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO respectively. Those on the Pd/ZnO catalyst showed some agglomeration (Fig. 2D). And some of the Pd NPs are seen not anchored on the CuO support. The recorded w % (weight % of Pd loading) obtained from the ICP-OES tests were Pd/Mn3O4-O (0.96 w %), Pd/Mn3O4-C (0.88 w%), Pd/TiO2 (1.1 w%), Pd/ZnO (0.78 w%) and Pd/CuO (0.56 w%) these were close to the 1 w % from the experimental value except in the cases of Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO. EDX (Fig. S2, page S4) and STEM elemental analysis (Fig. S3, page S5) of the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst showed that Pd was successfully loaded on the Mn3O4-O support with good dispersion. XPS and DRUV-vis spectra analysis XPS analyses of the supported Pd catalysts were conducted to check their valence electronic state and composition. The 3d5/2 for the Pd (0) component which is mostly observed at about 335 eV [24] shifted to higher energy levels whiles all the supports shifted to lower binding energy levels. For instance, the 3d5/2 zero valent values of the Pd species were 335.6, 335.4, 335.6, 335.8 and 336.0 eV equating to Pd/Mn3O4-O, Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and the Pd/CuO respectively, Fig. 3 . This could cause alterations in their Fermi energy levels induce synergy and promote strong metal-support (SMSI) interactions [15]. As observed in our previous works [15,25]. According to literature, the positive shift could correlate to difference in particle diameter, charge or chemical effects [26,27]. In the current work, we attribute it to charge and chemical effects since the Pd NP were relatively of the same size. The shifts are a confirmation of synergistic effect caused by alterations in the electronic characteristics of the Pd and the supports due to electron transfer. Furthermore, the estimated ratios of Pd (0)/Pd (II) from the respective XPS area intensities on the Pd/Mn3O4-O were 2.5, 1.1, 3.3 and 4.2 higher than the Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and the Pd/CuO respectively. XPS 2p spectra regions of the supports are reported in Fig. S4, page S6. The reported binding energy Mn 2p3/2 for Mn3O4 is 641.1 eV [28]. The observed values were 640.4 and 640.8 eV respectively for the Pd/Mn3O4-O and Pd/Mn3O4-C. That for Zn and Cu 2p similarly move to 1021.2 and 932.9 eV compared to the reported values 1022.7 eV [29] and 934 eV respectively [16]. The O1s spectra of the catalyst from their various XPS were analyzed and presented in Fig. 4 . Three distinct peaks were sorted from the asymmetric O1s XPS spectra of the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst, the band at 532.36 eV is dissociated or chemisorbed oxygen (OC), lattice (OL) oxygen groups are seen at 530.0 eV, and oxygen voids (OV) at 531.28 eV [15,30]. All tested catalyst show similar oxygen species but with varying intensities. In addition, all the peaks shifted to lower binding energies [28], which we ascribe to possible interactions with the remaining surface organic groups after calcination. The number and intensity of oxygen defects differed on all the catalyst. Nevertheless, OV was similar in the cases of Pd/Mn3O4-O and Pd/Mn3O4-C slightly higher than the Pd/TiO2 followed by the Pd/ZnO and the Pd/CuO showing the least. Abundant levels of Ov are reported to promote the catalytic abatement of C6H6 [31,32]. The estimated OV/OL (Table 1) from the O1s peak intensity of the catalysts was as follows Pd/Mn3O4-O, Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO. FTIR analysis Fig. S5, page S7, showed that some functional groups from the leaf extract remain on the Pd/Mn3O4-O after annealing which acts as stabilization agents. This agreed with the T.G tests of the Pd/Mn3O4-O at diverse annealing temperatrures (Fig. S6 and page S 8). H2 Temperature program reduction (H2-TPR) The ease at which a metal oxide reduces at low temperature corresponds to its reducibility and lattice oxygen transportability. And higher reduction temperature is often ascribed to limited oxygen mobility [33]. The supported Pd catalysts were assessed using H2 TPR, Fig. 5 . The reduction patterns are grouped into initial < 300 °C and later reduction peaks > 300 °C. The negative reduction peaks below 100 °C observed for all samples except the Pd/CuO are attributed to the formation of β PdH during the onset H2/Ar flushing and the progression of small amounts of Pd2+/Pd+ → Pd0 enhanced by H2 [34]. The peaks observed after 100 °C are ascribed to the gradual reduction of the various oxides. The as-prepared Pd/Mn3O4-O shows better reducibility compared to the other tested supported samples, its H2 consumption and transformation from Mn4+ → Mn3+/Mn2+/Mn+/Mn0 is enhanced compared to Pd/Mn3O4-C. The observed peaks at 158, shoulder peak at 250 and 430 °C are lower than the Pd/Mn3O4-C and those reported in literature (293, 462 °C for the first and second reduction peaks respectively) [7]. The Pd/TiO2 catalyst showed similar reduction profile but the transformation of Ti2+ → Ti+/Ti0 occurs at much higher reduction temperatures 345, 690 and 807 °C. Meanwhile, the Zn2+ → Zn+/Zn0 in the Pd/ZnO sample are observed from 415 °C and did not terminate even after 800 °C. The initial reduction peak of Pd in the Pd/CuO is not seen because of low Pd metal loading as confirmed from the ICP-OES studies. Peaks for the transformation of Cu2+ → Cu0 are seen at 203, 371 and an un-terminated peak from about 800 °C. From the H2-TPR profiles the order of low reducibility was determined to be Pd/Mn3O4-O followed by Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and the Pd/CuO. All the supported catalyst show better reducibility compared to their respective metal oxides [35]. This is attributed to effective doping of the catalyst by small Pd NP and the preparation method. Ding et.al reported that catalyst synthesis procedure for Co-Al mixed oxide induced diverse reducibility of Co3+ in the catalyst, markedly affecting their oxidation activities [14]. Moreover, Li et al., reported a similar observation in the case of two dissimilar Mn3O4 catalyst annealed at 300 and 500 °C, the former showed three reduction profiles, and two for the latter [7]. The above examples prove that the reducibility of catalysts depend on their crystallite size, constituent and preparation methods. O2 and Benzene Temperature program desorption (O2 and Benzene-TPD) Peaks from 65 to 708 °C are seen from the O2-TPD analysis (Fig. 6 A), between the range of 50 to 900 °C for all tested samples. These peaks can be divided into three groups initial (O2 species), that is low temperature catalytic surface active (O2,O2− and O-) absorbed species < 300 ° C , mid-stage (O2 < 500 ° C ) and desorbed inward OL species > 500 ℃ associated with the transport of O2 from the lattice of the various metal oxides [34–36]. Among them surface (O2, O2− and O-) species are the most essential and their low temperature transport is paramount to benzene abatement. Pd/Mn3O4-O presents the lowest initial O2-TPD values (55–225 °C) followed by Pd/Mn3O4-C (73–235 °C), Pd/ZnO (81–200 °C) and Pd/TiO2 (97–205 °C). The Pd/CuO presents a dissimilar profile from the other supported catalyst with a broad peak (225–514 °C). Benzene-TPD was further conducted to ascertain the benzene adsorption/desorption ability of the catalyst (Fig. 6B). Three obvious desorption points are seen, initial weak desorption sites between 30–200 ° C and then two strong ones > 200 °C. Pd/Mn3O4-O (56–160, 287 and 527 °C) and Pd/Mn3O4-C (56–160, 416 and 555 °C) presented all the three desorption peaks but at different temperatures. Pd/TiO2 and Pd/CuO presented two desorption peaks a broad one which terminates at 271 and 333 °C and the second peaks at 412 °C and 530 °C respectively. And the Pd/ZnO catalyst showed a single strong peak which terminates at about 550 °C. The results suggest that the Pd/Mn3O4-O adsorbs benzene better than the other catalyst. And the intensity shows the benzene adsorption first occurs on the strong adsorptive acid sites. Furthermore, since the first step in the abatement of benzene is the adsorption of benzene on the catalyst, the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst is expected provide more adsorbed benzene species increasing its reaction rate [37,38]. NH3-Temperature program desorption The availability, distribution and depth of acidic areas on the catalyst were explored using NH3-TPD within 100 to 900 °C. The observed peaks in Fig. 7 , can be divided into weak ( < 300 ℃ ) mid (between 300 < 500 ℃ ) and strong acid sites > 500 ℃ [39]. The Pd/Mn3O4-O shows a wide distribution covering all three acid sites. All other catalyst showed mid and strong acid sites but the peak intensities were pronounced on Pd/Mn3O4-C and Pd/CuO compared to Pd/TiO2. And Pd/ZnO showed the least acid sites. The order of total acidic sites estimated from the peak areas was proposed as Pd/Mn3O4-O > Pd/Mn3O4-C ≈ Pd/CuO > Pd/TiO2 and then Pd/ZnO. Based on the NH3-TPD profile and literature the order of Brønsted acid sites were estimated to be Pd/Mn3O4-O > Pd/TiO2 > Pd/Mn3O4-C > Pd/CuO and the Pd/ZnO. And Lewis acid sites were Pd/TiO2 > Pd/Mn3O4-O > Pd/ZnO > Pd/CuO and Pd/Mn3O4-C [40,41]. The catalyst acidic sites can influence the benzene adsorption/desorption ability of the catalyst [5,42]. Catalytic activity evaluation Fig. 8 A, presents the benzene oxidation activity of the as-synthesized Pd/Mn3O4-O to less harmful forms CO2 and H2O compared to Pd on commercial supports. Pd/Mn3O4-O and Pd/TiO2 showed close oxidation activity, T 100 conversion (the temperature at which conversion reaches 100%) at 240 °C. However, it showed a better initial activity than Pd/TiO2. It’s T 90 (the temperature at which conversion reaches 90%) and T 50 (the temperature at which conversion reaches 50%) were 206 ± 2.1 and 170 ± 1.8 °C, 6 and 11 °C lower than the Pd/TiO2 catalyst. Compared to the other Pd supported catalyst, the difference in performance was marked. The Pd/Mn3O4-C catalyst presented a T 100 at 260 °C, Pd/ZnO at 280 °C and the Pd/CuO showed the worse performance at 300 °C. The benzene oxidation reaction over supported metal oxides catalyst is determined by two critical factors, firstly the catalyst ability to trap surface adsorbed oxygen groups which promotes the oxygen transportability to enhance activity. And secondly the benzene absorption/adsorption rate over the catalyst. OV in metal oxide catalyst plays a significant part in their performance [31]. And low reduction temperature of a catalyst is associated to an abundant amount of lattice oxygen of the catalyst [43]. This is promoted by Pd-support synergy, minute grain sizes and large surface areas. The O2-TPD and H2-TPR test confirmed that the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst was more reducible at lower temperatures and could easily trap surface adsorbed oxygen groups which promote the oxygen transportability of the catalyst compared to the other tested catalyst. In addition, its benzene absorption/adsorption rate was better than all tested catalyst. Moreover, from the O1s test, Pd/Mn3O4-O showed the highest OL/Ov corresponding to more Mn-O bonds about 1.3, 1.2, 2.1 and 3.8 more than the Mn-O, Ti-O, Zn-O and Cu-O of the Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO catalyst respectively. This was consistent with the O2-and benzene TPD characterizations. As such the reaction is seen to be promoted by weak Pd-Mn–O bonds of the Pd/Mn3O4-O [44,45]. Another determining factor in catalytic oxidation reactions is the Brønsted acid sites, which affects the surface acidic or base characteristics of the catalyst. And controls the actual adsorption/desorption frequency of the products and reactants [46]. The NH3-TPD test showed the Pd/Mn3O4-O possessed more acidic sites followed by the Pd/TiO2 catalyst compared to the other catalysts. The existence of Brønsted acid sites could promote desorption of adsorbed surface active O2 (O2, O2- and O-) creating active sites to adsorb benzene [5]. Additionally, comparing the most active catalysts Pd/Mn3O4-O and the Pd/TiO2 to the least performing catalysts Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO, the Pd dispersion on their support surface was limited, Table 2 . And the Pd/ZnO catalyst showed an increased in particle size (3.6 nm) with some agglomeration and with the Pd/CuO (4.3 nm) some of the particles were seen not anchored on the support. Moreover, the ICP-OES showed the Pd loading was not effective on the ZnO and CuO probable due to their small BET surface areas 14.6 and 7.1 m²/g. The effect of metal dispersion on support is well document in literature [42]. Kim showed that Cu particles supported on γ -Al3O4 was more active than different supports (TiO2-anatese, TiO2-rutile, SiO2 (I) and SiO2 (II)) due to effective dispersion rather than specific surface area in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs [42]. And a close phenomenon was described by Wang et al., in oxidation of toluene, 5 wt% Cu/CeO2 was more active than Cu/ γ -Al3O4 due to difference in dispersion [47]. Furthermore, He et al., proved that, the improved catalytic ability of Pt0.3Mn5/SiO2-nc over other synthesized catalysts was because of improved Pt dispersion and strong Brønsted acid sites [5]. The difference in catalytic activities therefore seemingly correlates to their respective physicochemical characteristics such as available active O2 species and surface areas, crystallite size, acidic sites, chemical state and composition as supported by the various characterizations. The influence of nobel metal loadings and Pd particle sizes on catalytic performances are discussed in SI, page S 10. The stability and H2O-repellent properties of the as-formed Pd/Mn3O4-O were tested and presented in SI, page S 11, Fig. S9. And the kinetic and turn over frequency studies are presented in SI, page S 12, Fig. S10. CO2 selectivities of the various tested catalyst at diverse temperatures are presented in Table S 1. C6H6 abatement comparison of the Pd/Mn3O4-O with reported literature at same C6H6 concentration and space velocity shows it performance is commendable, Table S2. In situ DRIFT of C6H6 abatement using the Pd supported catalysts Fig. 9 presents the in-situ DRIFT spectra of the activity of the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst over 1000 ppm of N2/benzene feed gas with a 50 mL per min rate of flow at 40–210 °C for 30 min. The bands at 3724 and 3680 cm−1 are credited respectively to acidic areas on the catalyst and OH- surface groups [48]. Those at 3431 and 3287 are attributed to water and the OH extending vibrations of Brønsted acid sites [46]. Moreover, the double peaks at 2332 and 2351 cm-1 are characteristics of the main product CO2 [49]. The one at 1825 cm-1 represents the HC extending vibrations of adsorbed C6H6. The peak at 1571 cm-1 is as a result of phenolate groups [50]. Moreover, the ones observed at 1120, 1076 and 1012 cm-1 are associated with OC extending vibrations of RO- types [51]. Furthermore, those at 1646, 1482 and 1327 cm-1 are credited to OC extending vibrations of C6H4O2 types and the one at 936 cm-1 is as a result of CH2 bending vibration [51]. The in situ DRIFT spectra of C6H6 abatement of all the catalysts at 40 °C are shown in Fig. S10, page 14, when it is switched to O2/N2/benzene condition. All the catalyst showed similar spectra but the Brønsted acid sites show shifts and was unformed in the case of Pd/CuO. For example, those for the Pd/Mn3O4-C were observed at 3100 and 3055 cm−1 while those for Pd/ZnO and Pd/TiO2 were observed at 3100 and 3045 cm−1. Additionally, the C–O extending vibration of RO- types at 1120, 1076 and 1012 cm-1 in the spectrum of the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst are markedly promoted compared to the other catalyst, indicating the high absorption of benzene through the acid sites. More importantly, the main product CO2 located at 2329 and 2349 cm-1 and H2O at 3398–3427 are amplified under O2/N2/benzene conditions. Furthermore, peaks at 1646, 1482 and 1327 assigned mainly to the OC extending vibration of C6H4O2 types considered the tentative intermediates are observed for all catalyst at 40 °C. The benzoquinone species diminished at a faster rate (100 °C, Fig. 10 ) on the Pd/Mn3O4-O, followed by the Pd/TiO2, Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO respectively. And stabilize after a few minutes of reaction at 210 °C, Fig. S12, page 15. From the characterizations Pd/Mn3O4-O presented the least E a, the best TOF, high oxygen vacancy and the strong presence of acidic sites compared to the other catalyst which facilitates the improved performance over the other catalyst. Proposed oxidation mechanism A plausible reaction mechanism over the Pd/Mn3O4-O is proposed (Scheme 2 ) as follows; gaseous C6H6 is readily sucked up on the catalyst surface through the Brønsted acid areas and O2 molecules are activated to mobile oxygen types via the redox rotation of the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst. The benzene molecule is firstly assimilated on the Brønsted acid areas of the Pd/Mn3O4-O with the help of rich surface lattice oxygen/physisorbed oxygen, and alkoxide species (C–O-metal). Benzene is then converted to the phenolate and benzoquinone species through the possible abstractions of hydrogen atoms from the aromatic rings of C6H6 [51]. These intermediates then undergo further oxidation via the Pd/Mn3O4-O with surface lattice oxygen, physisorbed oxygen and alkoxide species over the acid sites. This leaves enough oxygen vacancies to trigger a continuously activated redox cycle to produce CO2 and H2O. Subsequently, benzene is converted to H2O and CO2. The low-temperature reducibility caused by addition of Pd and ample great-valence metal oxide storage of the Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst can enhance the redox rotation capability of Mn4+-Mn3+- Mn2+ to fabricate excess adsorbed oxygen groups. Importantly, the low E a, smaller crystallite sizes and easy reachable surface area of the Pd/Mn3O4-O compared to commercial supported catalyst are paramount to facilitate oxygen and benzene diffusion rates creating abundant active sites to fuel the C6H6 abatement reaction. Conclusion In conclusion, Pd supported on Mn3O4-O with improved acidic sites is compared with other Pd supported catalyst in the gas phase abatement of C6H6 at a large GSHV of 120,000 g−1 h−1·mL. The catalysts were synthesized by impregnation-assisted-biosynthesis a simple, inexpensive and environmentally-friendly approach that combines the strengths of the two processes and militates against the limitations of the impregnation process. Pd promotes reducibility of the supports due to hydrogen spillover induced by H2 dissociation of Pd. XPS analysis showed that exchange of electrons occurs between Pd and the support (Mn3O4-O, Mn3O4-C, TiO2, ZnO and CuO) inducing SMSI effect. The benzene oxidation reactions over the catalysts were influenced by acidic properties of the support, Pd particle diameter and dispersion. And the catalytic activity improved with Pd (2 ˜ 4 nm) and reduced with Pd > 4 nm mean particle size due to reduced dispersion on the support which limits the available active sites. The small crystallite size and abundant acid sites on the Pd/Mn3O4-O promotes its low temperature reducible, ability to readily trap surface O2 species and improved benzene absorption/desorption rate. Its high-valance metal oxide station and weakened Pd-Mn-O bond enhances the Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+ redox cycle ability over the other tested catalyst resulting in commendable O2 transportability as low as 140 °C. The Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO were hardly active below 200 °C due to poor Pd loading and dispersion which inhibits their ability to generate surface active O2 from their low-valence metal oxide station. In situ DRIFT studies showed that absorption of benzene over the catalyst occurred via the strong Brønsted acid and the alkoxide sites. Then the main intermediate species benzoquinone generated from the transformation of phenolate species and/or the abstractions of hydrogen atoms from the aromatic rings of C6H6 are oxidized to CO2 and H2O. The green high efficient but cost-effective Pd/Mn3O4-O catalyst also presented excellent stability over 120 h of reaction and a commendable immunity against H2O vapor a trait marked for industrial utilization making Pd/Mn3O4-O promising in the oxidation of benzene. coredata.dc:description: The activity of supported Pd catalyst as a result of metal oxide support (zinc, titanium, copper and manganese) is explored in the abatement of C6H6 in the gas-phase. The high-activity and cost-effective catalysts were synthesized utilizing impregnation assisted biosynthesis (IB) method. NH3-TPD, XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, XPS, O2 and Benzene-TPD, SEM and in situ DRIFT were done to probe their physicochemical characteristics and predict the plausible oxidation mechanism. Pd particle size and dispersion, and support active acid sites were the determining factors for activity. These factors markedly affected the catalyst ability to generate surface active O2 species from the metal oxides lattice station and controlled the benzene absorption/desorption rates. The as-synthesized Pd/Mn3O4-O with small crystallite size, good Pd dispersion, improved acid sites, and low activation energy (Ea = 45.3 kJ/mol) showed commendable O2 transportability and activity as low as 140 °C, GHSV of 120,000 mLg−1 h−1. Its T 100 at 240 °C was similar to Pd supported on TiO2 but was 20, 40 and 60 °C better than Pd/Mn3O4-C, Pd/ZnO and Pd/CuO. In situ DRIFT studies showed that the main intermediate species benzoquinone are oxidized to CO2 and H2O through the alkoxide and acid sites. Moreover, it was stable and highly resistant to H2O vapor.
coredata.dc:title: Towards efficient Pd/Mn3O4 catalyst with enhanced acidic sites and low temperature reducibility for Benzene abatement
